row.c_title: How Writing to Deadlines Can Hold Your Life Together
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum reflects on the surprising benefits of having to write a Lingua Franca post every week for seven years.

row.c_title: How Google’s Autotype Contradicts Orwell’s Advice
row.h_desc: To Geoff Pullum’s amusement, Gmail now offers phrases that are exactly the opposite of what the author of Nineteen Eighty-Four said writers should use.

row.c_title: The Web Page That Cannot Exist
row.h_desc: A tiny error on a conference web page provides Geoff Pullum with a concrete example for teaching abstract concepts in philosophy.

row.c_title: A Pocket Brexicon for American Academics
row.h_desc: Academics visiting Britain from the United States this holiday season will have trouble understanding some new words in the newspapers. Geoff Pullum has prepared a helpful Brexit glossary.

row.c_title: Blasphemy and the Strange World of Linguistic Crimes
row.h_desc: The medieval crime of saying things that outrage the pious exists in the 21st century, says Geoff Pullum, making a “safe space” for religion written into the law in some lands.

row.c_title: A Moment of Sympathy for the Old Fogeys and Snoots
row.h_desc: In the matter of “can not” vs. “cannot,” Geoff Pullum detects a flicker of fellow-feeling for the judgmental prescriptive usage pontificators of the world.

Geoff Pullum was asked to write a book about his field for a lay audience and publisher. Two favorable referee reports left him feeling alone and deprived of counsel, so he resorted to the judgment of that harshest but most biased of referees, the one inside his head.

row.c_title: Sir Harold Evans Sneers at a Book He Has Not Read
row.h_desc: Why would a man modify a book on good writing by adding a misguided slur and a misattributed quotation? Geoff Pullum wonders, resentfully.

row.c_title: Pure Gold, Buried Long Ago in the Book Review Columns
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum recalls a prescient observation about the relations between language and psychology, lost seven decades ago in a place so obscure you would never have found it.

row.c_title: What’s in a Name? A Government Loses a National Referendum Over an Adjective
row.h_desc: A referendum to add “North” to a country’s name failed after its president called the renaming “historical suicide.” Geoff Pullum explains why that’s ridiculous.

row.c_title: What’s the Fastest-Growing Language in the U.S.? You’ll Never Guess
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum reflects on its rapid spread, the significance of its language family to linguists, and some important speakers.

row.c_title: Nonsense About Universal Translation, Strictly for the Gullible
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum is optimistic about linguistics’ application for practical matters. So why do news outlets perpetuate crazy talk about translating animal language?

row.c_title: How the Cold, Dead Hand of John Dryden Still Perpetuates Grammar Myths
row.h_desc: The fiction about not ending sentences with a preposition can be traced back to the whims of one influential 17th-century writer, says Geoff Pullum. And that’s not all.
Is it “a number of X are” or “a number of X is”? It depends. Geoff Pullum discovers that Merriam-Webster’s Concise Dictionary of English Usage will not help you decide.

row.c_title: The Perennial Difficulty of Defining What ‘Descriptive’ Means in Grammar
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum is locked in an intractable dispute with a colleague about whether so-called descriptive work on English grammar is in fact prescriptivism in sheep’s clothing.

row.c_title: Chinese Among High-School Seniors (and in the Movies)
row.h_desc: Mandarin is overtaking German among college-bound high-school seniors. Geoff Pullum reflects on what that might mean, and what the job prospects are.

row.c_title: Learning Useless English Grammar in Japan
row.h_desc: A teacher of English sends Geoff Pullum some puzzling exam questions on an arcane corner of grammar. Japanese students are not just drilled on such sentences, he finds, but examined on them in crucial university admission tests.

row.c_title: Avoiding ‘False Titles’: How Some News Publications Try Not to Sound Like News Publications
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum enlists Lane Greene of The Economist to explain why the magazine insists on using explanatory phrases, as in “Uber, a ride-hailing company,” instead.

row.c_title: The Grammar of the Adjective Is Not What’s Wrong With ‘Illegal Alien’
row.h_desc: The Justice Department’s order that undocumented people should be called illegal aliens smacks of Newspeak but is linguistically unobjectionable. What’s nasty is the attitude behind it.

row.c_title: What’s an Anti-Semite? It Depends on Which Politician You Ask
row.h_desc: Can lexicography help solve political disputes about who is or isn’t anti-Semitic? Geoff Pullum doesn’t think so.

row.c_title: Writing on Philosophy: It’s Not Rocket Science. It’s More Complicated Than That.
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum tackles a perfectly formed yet extraordinarily complex and demanding sentence from a recent text. Can he wrestle it into simpler form?

row.c_title: Friendly Communication Across Supposed Language Barriers
row.h_desc: A conversation in a neighborhood shop reminds Geoff Pullum that despite the hostility between India and Pakistan, spoken Hindi and Urdu are almost identical.

row.c_title: The Triumph and Tragedy of Oscar Wilde
row.h_desc: A London performance of An Ideal Husband prompts Geoff Pullum to reflect on all that has changed, 120 years too late for the playwright, since its debut.

row.c_title: Koko Is Dead, but the Myth of Her Linguistic Skills Lives On
row.h_desc: Despite people’s wishful thinking, the famous gorilla did not master sign language, writes Geoff Pullum, but was producing random signs, notably in situation-bound efforts to get food from her trainer.

row.c_title: Strunk at 100: A Centennial Not to Celebrate
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum argues that professors should stop sending students to a thoroughly outdated writing guide — and cites some alternatives.

row.c_title: Another Conquest by the Language That Is Eating the World
row.h_desc: In the Netherlands, colleges are expanding their enrollments by offering courses in English, says Geoff Pullum.

row.c_title: Infinitives Can Be Split: Grammar Conservatives Face the Shock
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum examines the reaction in the letters column to a recent surprising announcement by The Economist. Could Lingua Franca have helped strengthen the magazine’s resolve?

row.c_title: Amazon’s Alexa: Not Yet as Smart as a 5-Year-Old Child
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum says natural-language processing is not ready for prime time, much less Amazon Prime.

row.c_title: The Israel/Palestine Dispute Is Ill-Served by Uninformed Grammar Nitpicking
row.h_desc: Ethno-geopolitical affairs in the Middle East are complex, says Geoff Pullum. We do neither side any favors by discussing the tragic maelstrom of hostilities through ignorant quibbles about language.

row.c_title: Hello, Google Duplex? No Artificially Intelligent Calls, Please
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum, examining a new development in artificial intelligence, decides that he’s inclined to continue making his own phone calls.

row.c_title: Fish, Cheese, and Gossip: 2,000 Years of Snobbery in the Suffix ‘-Monger’
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum detects more than a hint of millennia-old bias in words like warmonger.

row.c_title: Watergate, Weinergate, and Windrush: the Naming of Political Scandals
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum tracks some of the word-formation processes involved in the coining of names for new media firestorms.

row.c_title: Emoji Are Ruining Grasp of English, Says Dumbest Language Story of the Week
row.h_desc: Poppycock, says Geoff Pullum. Dropping the occasional pictograph into their prose is not going to strip people of the capacity to form sentences.

row.c_title: Can You Explain What a Shibboleth Is?
row.h_desc: Hearing BBC Radio use the word incorrectly, Geoff Pullum examines its Hebrew etymology and ancient history.

row.c_title: Copy Editing and Proofreading a Book: It Takes a Village
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum tackles the editing and proofing of a short book on why linguistics matters, and is glad he wasn’t trying to do it alone.

row.c_title: The Problem with the Ban on ‘There Are’ Constructions
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum wonders why usage advisers are so determined to get us to stop writing “there is” and “there are.” Some existentials (as clauses with those expressions are called) can’t be gracefully rephrased.
Geoff Pullum analyzes the subtle semantic underpinning of Cynthia Nixon’s amusing “unqualified lesbian” quip.

row.c_title: The Adverb That Killed a Friendship
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum watched as a monosyllabic, unstressed adverb terminated a neighborly relationship.

row.c_title: Taleb on Pinker: Neologism and Bile
row.h_desc: Having browsed the latest books by each of these two noted public intellectuals, Geoff Pullum reaches a decision.
Geoff Pullum argues that spam invitations to junk journals and concocted conferences are not just annoying; they do actual harm.

After clashing with his editor at The Chronicle on a point of grammar, Geoff Pullum exhumes the work of the two Edwardian eccentrics responsible for the myth that subjects of “verbal nouns” must always be in the possessive.

English syntax does change, says Geoff Pullum, but hardly at all over short time spans like 100 years. Failing to realize that is one of the mistakes made by doom-mongers who believe English itself is under threat.

row.c_title: No Overtime Pay for Milk-Truck Drivers (or Professors)
row.h_desc: No overtime pay; Geoff Pullum explains.

row.c_title: Talking Killer Whales? Gullible Science Journalists More Likely
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum is horrified by how willing journalists are to represent any kind of signaling or signifying as “language.”
A high school in Taiwan poses to its ninth-graders a grammar question about negative vs. positive clauses, and it worries Geoff Pullum a lot.
Would it improve the book you’re writing if you tried to avoid the most frequent verb in the language? Geoff Pullum scrutinizes an article that says it would.
Computer scientists say that students’ ability to write careful sentences in their native language correlates with success in programming courses. Geoff Pullum explains why.

row.c_title: ‘A Foreign Way Which Never Really Caught On’
row.h_desc: What would have been Muriel Spark’s 100th birthday is coming up. Geoff Pullum has an appreciation.

row.c_title: The Boy from the Isle of Man
row.h_desc: What happens to people who can’t decide whether to go into language study or science? If they’re lucky, they find themselves in linguistics, as Geoff Pullum explains.
Geoff Pullum tries his hand at crafting evocative oenological descriptions. Can you top them?

row.c_title: The Fine Line Between Errors and Dialect Differences
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum wrestles with the sentence “Imagine if I hadn’t of been there!”
Geoff Pullum recalls the humor of a philosopher of cognitive and linguistic science (Steven Pinker called him “brilliant, hilarious, maddening, influential, irreplaceable”): the late Jerry Fodor.

row.c_title: The Unmentionable Topic of Edinburgh Weather
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum weaves a remarkable tale about Robert Louis Stevenson, anarthrous nouns (those lacking articles), and the weather in “yon Empress of the North.”

row.c_title: Answering a Question with a Question
row.h_desc: Understanding sub-rosa inferencing and assumption-making is crucial to understanding how languages are really used, says Geoff Pullum.

row.c_title: The Right to Tell People What They Do Not Want to Hear
row.h_desc: That dictum of George Orwell’s pleases Geoff Pullum more than anything the author of 1984 ever said about language.
Geoff Pullum looks aghast at the array of evidence suggesting that people still worry irrationally about ending sentences with the part of speech that would do it the best.

row.c_title: The Ballad of Bentley and Craig
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum recounts a sad crime story that began 65 years ago today and ultimately hinged upon forensic linguistics.
“There is no such thing as correct style,” writes the BuzzFeed copy chief. Geoff Pullum explains why she doesn’t mean it.

row.c_title: The Strange Language of Harvey Weinstein’s Denial
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum trains a grammarian’s eye on the tortured wording of a statement issued by the film producer’s spokeswoman.
Is Geoff Pullum educable? He knows the rules of academic writing and Chronicle style, yet he still commits one error after years of training.

row.c_title: On the Ropes at Radio London
row.h_desc: London cheers as Geoff Pullum, learned professor, gets thwacked on a breakfast talk show.

row.c_title: The Subtle Art of English Ethnic Slurs
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum marvels at how English newspapers convey ethnic insults without using tabooed slur words.

Every day, software serves us messages that are morphologically, syntactically, and semantically aberrant, says Geoff Pullum. This means linguistics is not being applied in the single most important arena that needs it: artificial intelligence.
Geoff Pullum draws an analogy between testing for grammatical and chemical properties, with a reminder that (as Einstein said) things should be made as simple as possible, but not simpler.
Most grammar books are unredeemed horse dung from cover to cover, says Geoff Pullum. But he salutes one by a philosopher who understands parts of speech.
Geoff Pullum studies a how-to guide for New York Times contributors, and finds evidence that it cannot possibly be taken seriously.
Geoff Pullum asks: Why should some perpetrators of random mass murder be accorded the honor of promotion to a higher grade of homicide bearing the “terror” tag?

row.c_title: Didn’t Know I Would Really Go
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum discusses the extraordinary songs of Jimmy Webb, whose foremost musical collaborator and vocal interpreter died of Alzheimer’s last week.

row.c_title: Robots Gossiping in a Secret Language?
row.h_desc: Deliberate alarmist mendacity? Or journalists as gullible as babies? To be charitable, Geoff Pullum tentatively assumes the latter.

Geoff Pullum laments that what makes a hot story about language for the news media is not the fascinating new technological applications of linguistics, but that some schoolboy used an extra-long word. Talk about fake news.
Geoff Pullum spots a new member of a small category of words that hardly ever lets in a new member.
Adverbs becoming extinct, replaced by adjectives? Not so fast: The syntactic facts suggest otherwise, says Geoff Pullum.
Geoff Pullum marvels at a syntactic illusion that makes a sentence seem grammatical even though it can’t be.
Geoff Pullum’s shyness about grammar has gotten him nowhere. For a talk at the British Library, the gloves are coming off.

row.c_title: Worst Sentence Ever Seen in Academic Prose
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum attempts to parse an impossibly clumsy sentence written by a 19th-century philologist. Don’t tell him people knew how to write back then.
Geoff Pullum explains their similarity with regard to language.

row.c_title: Why Won’t They Heed Plain Facts?
row.h_desc: An exasperated Geoff Pullum wonders why there seems to be no way to convince grammar conservatives that rules of usage should find support in well-written prose.

row.c_title: Dracula, Strunk, and Correct English Usage
row.h_desc: One of the authors of The Elements of Style might have learned a thing or two had he read Bram Stoker, says Geoff Pullum.

row.c_title: Being a Declarative (or Interrogative, or Imperative, or Exclamative)
row.h_desc: Concerned at the chaotic and confused presentations in grammar books and on websites, Geoff Pullum provides a clear account of clause type, plus a homework.

row.c_title: The Importance of Being a Prince
row.h_desc: Having royal blood saves some heads of state from themselves, says Geoff Pullum. Then there are others.

Geoff Pullum helps investigate a fictive “grammar blunder.” His reward is to be misquoted and to get no answer when he complains (though a correction is quietly made later). And journalists wonder why academics are sometimes reluctant to take their calls.

row.c_title: The Risky Business of Deadpan Humor
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum attempts an April Fool’s metahoax and is chagrined when at least one reader falls for it.
Geoff Pullum says United Airlines shows its linguistic ineptitude even in the grammar of its contract of carriage; no wonder they talked their way into a PR disaster.

row.c_title: The Many First Rules of Politics
row.h_desc: A new one has bubbled up, says Geoff Pullum: Never compare anyone to Hitler. Poor Sean Spicer.
Geoff Pullum wishes a happy 80th birthday to his mentor and friend Rodney Huddleston, and explains why he’s such a central figure in the grammar world.

row.c_title: The Team Sat in Its Hotel Drinking Its Beers
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum is appalled by a Business Insider piece peddling indefensible myths about the use of “they” to a readership that should know better.
Hail, hail, rock and roll: Geoff Pullum remembers the poetry of Charles Edward Anderson Berry.
Geoff Pullum bemoans the cruel fate that has dragged him away from linguistics and into realms like file conversion software.

row.c_title: Data Mining for Personally Targeted Politics
row.h_desc: Recent developments suggest that current technology can utilize data about your thoughts and preferences for political ends, says Geoff Pullum. You should worry.

row.c_title: Once More Into the Fray, Pluto (and Ixion, Among Others)
row.h_desc: A planet by any other name, writes Geoffrey Pullum, has just as much gravitas as it ever did. And yet people agonize over how “planet” is to be defined.
Geoff Pullum is on the hunt for an extraordinarily rare type of sentence; this week he almost thought he’d found one.

row.c_title: For Want of a Copy Editor the Sense Was Lost
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum finds several errors in a scientific paper published by Elsevier, including in the title.
If Mandarin is to be taught to non-native speakers, says Geoff Pullum, it should focus on everyday, spoken language and not on rarefied words.

row.c_title: When Two Negatives Don’t Make a Positive
row.h_desc: The double-negative problem makes frequent appearances in grammar-and-usage guidebooks. Geoff Pullum argues it should be ditched.
Geoff Pullum, finding himself involved with a Burns Night Supper in Edinburgh, approaches a daunting linguistic task.

row.c_title: Agency Style, For Your Eyes Only
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum cautiously reveals some of the intelligence he gleaned from a look into the CIA’s editorial style guide.
Geoff Pullum, encountering an article about testimony in the trial of the man who shot Trayvon Martin, notes that the contempt sometimes poured on nonstandard dialects can have terrible consequences.

row.c_title: If Only I Could Tell You
row.h_desc: Which is preferable, “If only it were,” or “if only it was”? Geoff Pullum explains why both are correct.
The caricature of the English-professor advocates of laxity with their “softness” and cozy professorships has endured down the decades, says Geoff Pullum. But where are they?
Geoff Pullum reads about a student who thinks English accents are not proper English … and has a reaction to it that you might not expect.

row.c_title: For Want of an Oxford Comma
row.h_desc: Clarity for the reader should take priority over rigid enforcement of an arbitrarily stipulated rule of punctuational table manners, says Geoff Pullum

Geoff Pullum finds that Arrival isn’t the space-aliens movie he was expecting, and it isn’t really about linguistic analysis. It’s a moving story about something else entirely. (Caveat lector: Geoff makes no attempt to avoid spoiler plot revelations.)

row.c_title: The Unoriginality of Orwell’s Critique of Language
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum discovers that the ideas in Orwell’s “Politics and the English Language” are much less novel than is widely believed.

For years gangs of sexual abusers in English towns were ignored because authorities feared that acting against them would bring allegations of racial prejudice. But critical comment on a monoethnic crime gang does not make you a racist, says Geoff Pullum.
Geoff Pullum draws a general linguistic moral from the way that jokes and sayings spread, and attributions and authorship become obscured.

row.c_title: An Ill Wind That No One Blows Good
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum tracks the chaos of competing misattributions of a famous abusive description of a musical instrument.

row.c_title: Orgies, Convoys, and Precision in Word Meanings
row.h_desc: The unlikely topic of how many participants it takes to make an orgy leads Geoff Pullum to reflect on the remarkable failure of human languages to provide for exactness of meaning.

row.c_title: The Internet Isn’t Changing English. Nor the Converse
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum is mystified by recent claims about the web causing revolutionary changes in language.
Geoff Pullum relaxes with five German-speaking friends, eager for a little conversational experience. But that is not what he gets.
Geoff Pullum’s undergraduate teaching this semester includes a voyage of space exploration: the space used for representing vowel quality.
Geoff Pullum coined that useful word to denote a special day repeated each month. But like many innovations people imagine they see in English, it had been invented before.
Geoff Pullum, in the Czech town of Brno, ponders some tempting analogies between prose style and architectural style.
The candidate’s sentences mean what they mean, semantically, says Geoff Pullum. The question is whether they can pragmatically imply something distinct from their literal meaning.
Geoff Pullum attends a seminar on a vampire novel, led by Eula Biss, author of a book on vaccination. And he learns that vampires aren’t the only repulsive creatures hiding in the shadows.
One day, machines have to be made able understand what we say in our native languages, and tell us things effectively, says Geoff Pullum. But right now they don’t.
Geoff Pullum does a close reading of what exactly Donald Trump said about ‘the Second Amendment people” and what they could do to stop a future President Clinton nominating judges.
Answering a colleague’s cry for help on how to pronounce a crucial literary word, Geoff Pullum and a friend discover half a dozen answers, with no sign of a way to decide among them.
Once every student was expected to master elementary grammar, logic, and rhetoric before proceeding to other liberal arts and sciences. Today, perhaps not so much, Geoff Pullum suspects.
Geoff Pullum finds a writing handbook that doesn’t just repeat the standard just-say-no dictat about the passive voice, but instead makes sensible points about when to use it.

row.c_title: The World’s Best Philosopher of Linguistics
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum uncovers the sad fact that his favorite philosopher of linguistic science died months ago, and he didn’t yet know.
Geoff Pullum looks into the origin of a Churchillian quotation that fails to make him smile the way it used to.
Geoff Pullum uncovers evidence that some 19th-century grammarians had completely lost their marbles.

row.c_title: Linguification: That’s the Name of the Game
row.h_desc: It’s a rhetorical device both defiant of logic and deeply silly, and its blithe acceptance annoys Geoffrey Pullum no end.
Geoff Pullum, in Germany to give a lecture, wonders if Britain will have voted to cut its links to the EU by the time he gets back.
Geoff Pullum pictures in his mind’s eye the crusty old editor who wrote the section on transitive verbs in a harshly judgmental style book.

row.c_title: Liars and Snakes: Plumbing New Rhetorical Depths
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum examines a serpentine metaphor that has slithered into British politics.
Geoff Pullum remembers with affection a few of the priceless things his late wife used to say.

row.c_title: Syntactic Self-Harm on St James’s Street
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum visits the headquarters of The Economist in a quest to find out why it insists on a style rule that is deleterious to clarity.
Geoff Pullum recalls the moment at which he lost his innocence regarding the infallibility of dictionaries.
Being asked for advice about whether a grammar test has been wrongly graded is one thing, Geoff Pullum decided, but demanding the answer as quickly as possible is quite another.

row.c_title: Famous Women, Banknotes, and Online Abuse
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum ruminates on why elementary recognition of women’s achievements attracts Internet hostility.

row.c_title: The Social Consequences of Switching to English
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum learns to his surprise of a case in which switching the language of business in a company from Japanese to English brought about a revolution in corporate culture.
Geoff Pullum tackles a dispute about a which-one-is-right grammar-test item that appears to be indefensible.
Geoff Pullum finds in his inbox an astonishingly flawed piece of writing, sent unsolicited by a commercial proofreading and editing company.
All speech and writing contain ambiguities about which pronouns refer to what, Geoff Pullum claims; they don’t have to, but they just seem to be poorly designed in that respect.
Some grammar purists seem to think the English subjunctive is a fragile creature in danger of extinction. As usual they can’t tell their adjective from their elbow, says Geoff Pullum.

row.c_title: Sentences I Hope Never to Use
row.h_desc: Some grammatical and meaningful sentences, quite commonly heard in real life, are nonetheless ones that Geoff Pullum hopes never to utter as long as he lives. Read a short sampling.
Geoff Pullum agrees with Mark Liberman of Language Log in appreciating the linguistic insight often seen in the opinions and dissents of the late Justice Scalia.
Don’t mistake emoji for words, or sequences of emoji for sentences, says Geoff Pullum. Most of them are nothing of the kind.

row.c_title: Leaps in the Dark: the Discourse of Brexit
row.h_desc: Slogans, fearmongering, and clichés are what the British people are getting, says Geoff Pullum. That’s not what they need.
Geoff Pullum firmly endorses a sentiment expressed by Steven Pinker: Words have multiple meanings, and taking offense at unintended senses or associations of words is neither rational nor mature.

row.c_title: To Co-Author, or Not to Co-Author?
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum considers the business of collaborative research publication, and offers some words of advice based on long experience.
Most of the terms for death are euphemisms, and exist because people don’t want to discuss it at all. Geoff Pullum makes an exception.
” …till somebody new comes along.” Geoff Pullum celebrates the late Glenn Frey, author of many of the Eagles’ insightful lyrics.

The traditional writing system of the Chinese-speaking parts of the world has disadvantages that would, on their own, be sufficient to guarantee that Chinese will not become a global language like English, says Geoff Pullum.

Geoff Pullum is surprised to find two recent books from publishers in the same street have the same title, year of publication, and cover theme. And the same habit of uncritically parroting 18th-century dogma.
Never imagine that the discovery of plain, verifiable truths is the typical business of science, or that it is unknown in the humanities, argues Geoff Pullum.

row.c_title: The Footprints of a Gigantic Hound
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum browses a collection of quotes from the Holmesian canon, and discovers some literary history close to his home.
Geoff Pullum explains why he agrees with The New York Times Manual of Style, for once, about that phrase.

row.c_title: English and Its Undeserved Good Luck
row.h_desc: In higher education and the world, the dominance of English is inescapable, says Geoff Pullum; but to a large extent it is due to fortunate historical accidents.
Geoff Pullum reviews some of the shortcomings that make English a strikingly poor choice for a language of global communication.
Geoff Pullum, on a speaking trip to northern Spain, finds a delightful city on a sparkling river, and listens to an alien language; and, by lucky accident, avoids a night of horror.

row.c_title: Prepositions as Conjunctions, Whales as Fish
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum’s heart sinks as he sees a government-ordained test of grammar that requires children to give an incorrect 18th-century answer rather than a correct 21st-century one.
Geoff Pullum reflects on the surprising fact that many people still think “I Only Have Eyes for You” contains a grammatical error.

Ellen Bresler Rockmore says textbooks approved by the State of Texas are using passive-voice constructions to minimize Southern white responsibility for the horrors of slavery. Geoff Pullum examines the evidence in more detail.
Geoff Pullum reflects on a traditional definition of pronoun that has been repeated in grammar books for more than two centuries, despite its hopeless inadequacy.
Still ashamed of not having a conversational command of German, Geoff Pullum makes a start on it: Say “the” correctly.

row.c_title: The Third Flaw in the Second Amendment
row.h_desc: Reflecting on the Umpqua shootings, Geoff Pullum realizes there are not two but three flaws in the wording of the Second Amendment, all lending to its disastrous vagueness.
Geoff Pullum thinks the appallingly dumb behavior of the machines that currently talk to us does not bode well for the future of intelligent devices.

row.c_title: Sex and Verbs and Rock ’n’ Roll
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum reveals why he was recently browsing in a 40-year-old book about German grammar, and why a recent lecture invitation makes him feel ashamed.

row.c_title: Pointless Vocabulary Diversity and Grammatical Structure
row.h_desc: Can you help Geoff Pullum? Somewhere out there someone argued, citing examples, that school reading materials are dumbing down pupils’ sentence structure but increasing the proportion of rare and relatively useless words they know. Where and who was it?

row.c_title: Best Linguistic Jokes of the 2015 Fringe
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum keeps a promise: Read his Top 10 from the Edinburgh Fringe.
Geoff Pullum looks at the way universities name themselves, and points to a moral concerning language acquisition.
Geoff Pullum is shocked to discover a law-school course syllabus stating that students’ grades would be partially determined by adherence to a set of false claims about proper English usage.
Aren’t words like “pedophile” and “philanderer” formed from the wrong parts, having the wrong meanings in the original Greek? Geoff Pullum ponders the question.
Geoff Pullum looks at the name of a chemotherapy drug that has dozens of ways in which it could conceivably be pronounced, and realizes that the uncertainty gives rise to a danger.
In an old logic book Geoff Pullum stumbles upon a description of the two ways in which one can learn a foreign language. Neither could possibly work.

row.c_title: The Fringe Is Coming to Town
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum recalls some jokes from last year and looks forward to his favorite festival.
Geoff Pullum wakes up to find morning newspaper stories questioning not only what “one kilogram” means but even what “one” means.
Geoff Pullum realizes something about Orwell’s rhetoric that he never saw clearly before: Orwell is engaging in thought control through language while warning against it.
Birds in rural Australia using the building blocks of language? Geoff Pullum wonders why science journalists indulge in such wild overinterpretation of evidence about animal communication.
Geoffrey Pullum notes the 50th anniversary of a book by Noam Chomsky that laid the foundations for half a century of work in a whole cluster of disciplines.
Geoff Pullum has scant sympathy for the professor who wrecked his career with one brief gratuitous remark, but wishes that humor could have played a larger role in the world’s reaction.
Geoff Pullum demonstrates, with a little computer code, how even thousands of new words in the Scrabble dictionary are not going to make the game any easier.
Geoff Pullum clarifies the distinction between data and metadata, and suggests that concern over government access to the latter is paranoid craziness.
Geoff Pullum is unnerved by journalists lining up to humiliate 16-year-old Brooklyn Beckham over an understandable one-letter mistake.
Geoff Pullum gets unexpected help from meteorology in drawing a distinction that Noam Chomsky advocated 50 years ago.
Geoff Pullum explains the crucial distinction between optional and obligatory punctuation.
Geoff Pullum spots a pair of commas inserted wrongly by a copy editor, and jumps as if stung by a bee.
Being a visiting speaker looks like easy work, until you focus on the details. Geoff Pullum just returned from a lecture trip.
Geoff Pullum examines a published document that tests his faith in the principle that native speakers of a language generally deploy its grammar correctly.
Geoff Pullum deals with a correspondent’s puzzle over apparently acceptable phrases flagged by Microsoft Word as errors; and he does not take Microsoft’s side.
Geoff Pullum’s correspondent Professor Faxman explains the quantitative basis for his prejudice against passives; but he is profoundly mistaken.
Geoff Pullum receives a communication by an unusual medium, and is affronted by the abuse it contains.
Geoff Pullum looks at some of William Zinsser’s grammatically oriented advice about writing, and is shocked at what he sees.
Geoff Pullum reflects on the latest scandal emanating from the loose tongue of a presenter of the world’s most popular factual TV show.

row.c_title: Lain, the Whom of the Verb World
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum discusses a verb inflection tangle that is not just confusing but positively unfair to users.
Geoff Pullum recommends a course on elementary phonetics as a practically useful introduction to one aspect of human diversity.

row.c_title: Having a Problem With ‘Having a Problem With’
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum laments the idiomatic meaning of a phrase that regularly misleads him into an excess of charitableness.

row.c_title: Free Speech, the Rough and the Smooth
row.h_desc: Meet ignorant and offensive remarks with gentle linguistic humor rather than rage, says Geoff Pullum.
Geoff Pullum takes up the vexed question of whether “comprise” should be used to mean “compose,” and not in the way you expect.
An apparently novel phrase seems too implausible to have ever before occurred, but Geoff Pullum is surprised when he checks his intuition empirically.
Geoff Pullum faces social stratification, dialect differences, and a dilemma involving a word he needs to utter just about every day.
Instead of getting on with his grading, Geoff Pullum ruminates on the mistakes students always make in essay questions.

A startlingly idiosyncratic choice of “he” over “him” leads Geoff Pullum to ruminate on the trickiness of the pronoun case system in English, and to compare English with Australian aboriginal languages.

row.c_title: Renée Zellweger as a Verb? I Don’t Think So
row.h_desc: A ‘Washington Post’ columnist says the actress “has become a verb.” Geoff Pullum sees pretentious nonsense rather than profundity.
Geoff Pullum examines a rather surprising practice revealed in a forgotten paper published 100 years ago.
Geoff Pullum rediscovers a 100-year-old article that he finds strikingly superior to what passes for discussion of English language today.
Geoff Pullum visits a huge university where, thankfully, philosophy and philology have outlived intolerance and murder.
Geoff Pullum has been combating myths and falsehoods about language outside the classroom, too, including in The Guinness Book of Records.
It isn’t the competence of the users of English we should worry about, says Geoff Pullum, but the qualifications of the blunderers who set the grammar quizzes.

row.c_title: Writing Instructors: Your Pain Is Felt
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum has been grading papers, and he agrees that overuse of the passive is horrible to behold. But passives are not the real problem.
Geoff Pullum hears Steven Pinker’s mellifluous voice on the radio … and is frozen in horror at what Pinker says.

row.c_title: Talking About Word Aversion on TV
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum looks forward confidently to a forthcoming television appearance, with occasional nightmares about how it might go all wrong.
Geoff Pullum bristles at the suggestion that he lighten up and stop sinking his fangs into misguided grammar advice.

row.c_title: Dumb Writing Advice, Part 2: Yielding to Nitwits
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum says it is nothing short of professional misconduct to teach students falsehoods on the grounds that know-nothings might disapprove of the truth.

row.c_title: Dumb Writing Advice, Part 1: Word Prohibitions
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum says banning certain words is of zero help in getting people to write better prose.
People who try to make students drop their use of one common interjection, says Geoff Pullum, are wasting time and energy.
Two definitions of “subject of a sentence” have been kicking around for more than 200 years, says Geoff Pullum, and both are utter nonsense.
Geoff Pullum, living in Scotland, reflects on the inept sloganeering of the anti-independence campaign.

row.c_title: The Case of the Sinister Buttocks
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum takes a closer look at a global higher-education story about thesaurus-assisted plagiarism.
Geoff Pullum says that an inherent psychological property of students answers a criticism leveled at automatic computer essay-grading.
Geoff Pullum dares to take a shockingly positive view of the notion that essay-grading might be mechanized.

row.c_title: Grammatical Icing on the Political Cake
row.h_desc: Why, asks Geoff Pullum, would Elliott Abrams ruin the presentation of a political point by viewing it through the lens of an irrelevant and false claim about grammar?

row.c_title: Speaking Out Against Hate Speech (Or Not)
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum faces a clear opportunity to call someone out for a bigoted remark … and still can’t decide whether he made the right decision.

If you were to tell a hurdler, “lift your feet high enough to get over the hurdles without hitting them,” that would be useless advice, says Geoff Pullum. The same goes for familiar grammar rules for students.
Using “they” with a singular antecedent can lead to unclarity, Geoff Pullum warns. That doesn’t mean it’s bad grammar.
Geoff Pullum looks aghast at a piece of awful writing by the chief executive of Microsoft, a corporation bent on achieving world domination by platitudes.
Geoff Pullum says it isn’t spoken by as many people as the People’s Republic would have you believe, nor is it any harder to translate than other languages.

row.c_title: The True Secret of Office Packing
row.h_desc: A four-word remark vouchsafed to Geoff Pullum by a colleague provided an inspiration about bundling up your stuff for a move.
Geoff Pullum has the resolution to a grammatical dilemma. But you’re not going to like it, because it fails to submit you to the harsh discipline you crave.
Geoff Pullum begins to suspect that people are not just treating word taboo too seriously, they are losing their grip on which words are supposed to be taboo.
Geoff Pullum’s heart sinks as he finds that a guide to English grammar once again simply regurgitates useless 200-year-old platitudes.

row.c_title: The Vague Main Clause of the Second Amendment
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum reflects sadly on the amendment’s syntactic problems, which make gun control virtually impossible in America.
Geoff Pullum is shocked by the contrast in consequences between two cases in Britain involving public figures’ use of racist and sexist language.
Geoff Pullum discovers to his surprise that the technical term he has been encouraging Lingua Franca readers to invent has already been invented.
An English-literature professor at Cambridge sketches a distinction between grammarians who prescribe and those who describe; Geoff Pullum strongly objects.
Out of thousands of languages that could be the world’s primary language for higher education, would anyone have picked English? Geoff Pullum is skeptical.

row.c_title: And the Other Is a Jellyfish
row.h_desc: The British prime minister has suffered a sting, and Geoff Pullum sees a clear but unnamed pattern to the rhetorical structure of some of the resultant Twitter commentary.
Geoff Pullum learns why it can be safer to be outside the Balkans when discussing Balkan politico-linguistic matters.

Geoff Pullum explains why the failure of animals to master human languages does not incline him to feel superior to them. (And at the bottom of the post: the results of Ben Yagoda’s Language Madness competition.)
Geoff Pullum reads a dolphin-to-human communication story published on April 1, and for a moment he wonders: Could it be?
Geoff Pullum shared some views about English grammar with a journalist … and then unwisely looked at readers’ abusive reaction to the feature article that resulted.
Geoff Pullum risks displeasing purists both sides of the Atlantic by arguing that the differences between American and British English are trivial.

row.c_title: Brevity and Attractiveness: Misreporting Linguistic Science
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum reads a newspaper article and wonders how reporting so incredibly inaccurate could possibly come about.
Geoff Pullum tries to explain, with the help of Poe and an Italian wine crate, what it’s like to be a linguist.
Geoff Pullum is taken aback on discovering what appears to be a computer program that will write literate essays to order.
Geoff Pullum hears a Brazilian businessman say that the price of iron ore “came” from $10 to $180, and realizes that there is no guarantee that English will or ever could be logical.
Geoff Pullum ruminates on the astonishing effrontery of an electronic request that he receives repeatedly, and on what it has to do with Asimov’s Three Laws of Robotics.
From a newspaper sentence so badly composed that you cannot even tell how many people are being mentioned, Geoff Pullum draws a moral for us all.
Geoff Pullum takes Lynne Truss to task over a shocking charge that linguists are “broad-minded” about grammar mistakes.
A “Washington Post” writer claims “concern trolls thrive on passives the way vultures thrive on carcasses,” and Geoff Pullum wonders what on earth that could mean.

row.c_title: Moths to the Flame of Meaning
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum finds that undergraduates facing exam questions about grammar often flutter helplessly into discussing meaning instead.
On a site where theses and dissertations are reduced to single sentences, Geoff Pullum finds humor, poetry, cynicism, and despair.
The only linguist in the House of Lords had a chance to tell his colleagues to stop being sexist dinosaurs about singular “they,” says Geoff Pullum. But he didn’t.
To Geoff Pullum’s surprise, English teachers try to ban local dialect from their school, apparently unaware of relevant educational research from half a century ago.
Does Google really invade your privacy? Geoff Pullum reflects on how people can possibly believe Microsoft’s scare stories.

Students learning to write, says Geoff Pullum, need advice about what to do, and when, and how, if they are to navigate between sounding like a pompous great-grandfather and an overexcited high-schooler.
Even the principle that verbs have to agree with subjects, says Geoff Pullum, is so much more complex and subtle than simplistic writing advice assumes.
Why, Geoff Pullum asks, would a literature department hand its students a list of patronizing truisms and blatant falsehoods about writing?
Geoff Pullum ponders an epistemological question: how to be sure that the anonymous critical column he recently criticized was actually written by Oscar Wilde.

row.c_title: Linguistic Fuel for a Political Brushfire
row.h_desc: Did government ministers respond to rising energy prices by telling people to don sweaters? No, says Geoff Pullum, but the way negation works in English helped the news media to make it look that way.
Geoff Pullum is chagrined to discover the great Oscar Wilde endorsing a silly and hypocritical prescriptivist attitude to grammar.

row.c_title: The Higgs: Names Becoming Common Nouns
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum looks out of the window of a bus and sees a man whose name has become a technical term in physics.
Geoff Pullum is genuinely surprised to see a newspaper article about grammar making 10 points about the syntax of contemporary Standard English that are broadly correct.

row.c_title: Is the Cognitive Revolution Here Yet?
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum is at a conference on “the cognitive revolution.” Has it actually happened yet?

row.c_title: Can Goofy Headlines Cost You Money?
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum marvels at the ability of headline writers to make major conceptual mistakes at a rate exceeding one every three words.
Geoff Pullum is shocked to learn of English speakers facing sharp disapproval for their willingness to learn foreign languages.
A recent Chronicle article called grammarians intimidating, and Geoff Pullum wishes it wasn’t so (sorry, wishes it weren’t so).

row.c_title: Who’d Want to Be a Dick Swiveller?
row.h_desc: For 200 years people have been quoting and requoting “it was ever thus.” But why, asks Geoff Pullum, and from where?
Geoff Pullum explores a “lumper” view, which posits one Germanic language spoken from Hungary to Belgium, and a “splitter” view, which shows four or five languages on the Italian island alone.

row.c_title: Counting the Languages of the World
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum is reminded, after a dip into the Ethnologue, that counting languages is a perplexingly politicized and unscientific business.
Geoff Pullum worries about our reliance on tests that are sometimes reminiscent of a surprisingly difficult children’s game played on a radio station.
Our job as academic experts is not simply knowing stuff. It’s using what we know to find other stuff out. Or so Geoff Pullum decided when approached about something he knew nothing about.

row.c_title: Is Strunk Bunk? a Game-Changing New Development
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum is surprised to find his opponents deeming English literature inadmissible as evidence concerning the validity or invalidity of usage rules.
Critics speak of the last two pages of “The Great Gatsby” as truly superb writing. Would the author of “The Elements of Style” have given it an A? Geoff Pullum investigates.
Is political language really, as Orwell alleged, “designed to make lies sound truthful and murder respectable”? Geoff Pullum doubts it.

row.c_title: Extractor Fans, Big Brother, and the Passive
row.h_desc: Too often, writing advice opts for absolute prohibitions or requirements. Rather like building-safety codes, muses Geoff Pullum, as he relaxes, unsafely, in the bath.
Even basic usages like “besides” and “never mind” have yet to be correctly described, Geoff Pullum discovers in Santiago de Compostela.

row.c_title: You’re Wrong and I’m Changing the Subject
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum mulls over the most common responses by editors and publishers to evidence-based usage information: silence, rejection, and switching topics.
Geoff Pullum writes from a country united by a national language that its speakers pretend is three quite different languages. Go figure.

row.c_title: Getting In and Out (and Looked At)
row.h_desc: Students certainly do write unbalanced coordinations that cannot possibly be construed as grammatical, says Geoff Pullum, and that’s a descriptive rather than a prescriptive statement.
Google Translate does power guessing, says Geoff Pullum; and although we know we can’t trust it, with nowhere else to turn, we use it anyway.
Voice interaction with machines has been brought up to a useful level not so much by accurate identification of speech, says Geoff Pullum, but by structuring the space of possible conversations.

row.c_title: Keyword Search, Plus a Little Magic
row.h_desc: Looking for keywords in files was dumb until the discovery of a magic additive that made it usable, Geoff Pullum explains.

row.c_title: Why Are We Still Waiting for Natural Language Processing?
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum says computer systems should be able to understand simple English questions--and answer them.
Yes, a new word (“slash”) has joined the category of “conjunctions”; but, Geoff Pullum argues, that category should be renamed.

row.c_title: We Do Not Seek to Rule
row.h_desc: Linguists are not trying to encourage you to use constructions you don’t like, says Geoff Pullum; they seek enlightenment, not power.
Why, Geoff Pullum asks, are we reluctant to use the words “king” or “monarch” when talking about the hereditarily entitled absolute rulers of North Korea?

row.c_title: Orwell and the Not Unblack Dog
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum explains one of his reasons for seeing George Orwell’s “Politics and the English Language” as not just silly but intellectually dishonest.
Why, asks Geoff Pullum, does anybody take seriously George Orwell’s famous recommendation to avoid the phrases that figure most frequently in current writing?
Even under an extraordinarily plaintiff-friendly legal system, says Geoff Pullum, surely a librarian should not have been deemed vulnerable to a libel suit for comments on book quality?
A local government council that proposed dropping apostrophes from street-name signs faced fury from the guardians of punctuation. The guardians are mistaken, says Geoff Pullum.
The maligned adverb “quite” seems to have two opposite meanings, some people say. Not true, Geoff Pullum explains.

row.c_title: Spurious Correlations Everywhere: The Tragedy of Big Data
row.h_desc: It’s easy to find meaningless correlations in large bodies of data, Geoff Pullum says, making it less likely that an economist’s correlation of future tense with profligacy means anything.
A recent economics paper links lifestyle facts to grammatical properties of languages. Geoff Pullum wonders whether the proposed explanatory intuition holds up.
Geoff Pullum encounters a how-to-write-better column telling you to get rid of adverbs, and wonders how anyone could give such obviously dopey advice.
English is not in need of repair, says Geoff Pullum, disagreeing with the Washington State Legislature, which is trying to scour allegedly sexist words from its statutes.

Hardly anything discovered by linguists about language makes it through to presentations of grammar to the general public, Geoff Pullum says. A radical scientific shake-up of the notion of a preposition is a case in point.
Geoff Pullum discovers, to his astonishment, a paper by academics who mistook a humorous essay for an earnest scholarly paper, and attacked it on that basis.
From the charge of the absurdly vague term “hacking,” Geoff Pullum complains, you can hardly tell anything about what an accused person is supposed to have done.

The presentation of English grammar to the public is in a bad way, says Geoff Pullum. Just look (for instance) at the thousands of sites on the Web that endorse a definition of “adjective” that makes no sense.
A small slip in a preface by a German academic leads Geoff Pullum to reflect on how astonishing it is that we learn English as well as we do.
Geoff Pullum reflects on subordinate clauses, essay questions, teacher training, and an interesting experiment at a high school on Staten Island.
Geoff Pullum explains why a common misquotation of James Bond’s signature martini order is subtly incoherent, if you know your cocktail physics, and your conventional implicatures.

row.c_title: A Rule Which Will Live in Infamy
row.h_desc: Only hypocrisy, dishonesty, and pointless nitpicking result from the rule that supposedly bans “which” from restrictive relative clauses, says Geoff Pullum.

row.c_title: One Rule to Ring Them All
row.h_desc: Seeing an apparently incorrect “whom” in “The New Yorker,” a friend suggested to Geoff Pullum that perhaps the end of the world was nigh. But for the sort of example in question, the rules of Standard English actually fail to settle the matter.

row.c_title: Don’t Blame Your Moods on Your Language
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum objects to the suggestion of a recent article that the subjunctive is a lost art (it isn’t) and that its loss can play havoc with your emotions (not so).
How could an adjective meaning “correct” morph into an adverb meaning “completely”? Geoff Pullum’s students help him find out, and remind him how pleasurable teaching can be.
Geoff Pullum is worried that bickering over the failure to use the so-called subjunctive verb form “were” is needlessly wrecking a relationship.
Geoff Pullum explains the pseudoetymology of words like “Frankenstorm” and “frankenfood”—and “heliport” and “basketeria.”
Geoff Pullum explains why the plight of people whose immigration was unlawful won’t be helped by arguments about the grammar and meaning of “illegal immigrant.”

row.c_title: What Words to Say, What Sort of Person to Be
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum offers a reminder about why the principal obscene word of the English language can never become normal.

row.c_title: Passive Writing at the Daily Planet
row.h_desc: When Perry White warns the young Clark Kent against “passive sentence structure,” Geoff Pullum worries about the money wasted paying for students to be given advice that they can never follow because no one knows what it means.
Geoff Pullum opens yet another unsolicited attack on his character and competence, and reflects on what the writer actually means.
In west Providence, Geoff Pullum finds pleasure in exploring what the horrormeister H.P. Lovecraft feared.

Why should it be moving simply to stand outside a house where the consummate master of 20th-century supernatural horror lived and wrote? Geoff Pullum puzzles over the phenomenon of literary pilgrimage.
Reading the small print, Geoff Pullum realizes that, to his shame (some grammarian!), he failed to appreciate the consequences of the ingredients in a jar of fruit spread.
Geoff Pullum faces the challenge of communicating with an alien civilization, and finds it unremittingly strange.
Mechanically unsplitting infinitives can make prose worse and introduce needless ambiguity, says Geoff Pullum.

row.c_title: Even That Would Be a Grammar
row.h_desc: Grammarians get stereotyped, Geoff Pullum has found, either as rulebook-thumping martinets or as if-it-feels-good-do-it anarchists. But there is a third way that makes things much more interesting.

row.c_title: You Are Software; Don’t Greet Me
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum locates the source of the creepy feeling he gets when greeted in highly intimate, folksy way by a computer program that has no right to salute him at all.

row.c_title: The Riddle of Frisney and Frarney
row.h_desc: Who were they? What was the foreign guest talking about? The family was initially baffled. But they figured it out; Geoff Pullum explains how.
Spelling bees do no harm, but learning to spell bucketloads of rare words like “guetapens” has little educational value, says Geoff Pullum. That’s why we have dictionaries.

Tired of people sending him lists of allegedly Eskimo snow words, Geoff Pullum draws a lesson from a word for an implausible weather phenomenon, in a curious language spoken northwest of continental Europe.
Are you addressing a conference, or even just asking a question? Want to be heard? For heaven’s sake learn how to speak into the correct part of a microphone, begs Geoff Pullum.
Geoff Pullum reflects on how to word out-of-the-office vacation auto-reply messages over the summer.
Geoff Pullum sees nothing but foolishness, not to mention ignorance of grammar, in the paper’s recent article on language problems in the workplace.
On a trip in a punt along the backs of the Cambridge colleges, Geoff Pullum is shocked to discover that the young gondolier had never heard of one famous alumnus.
Geoff Pullum reflects on what sort of property could possibly link airspeeds and apples with absences, or connect organizations with orchids and orgasms.

row.c_title: When Your Computer Is as Easy to Use as Your Phone
row.h_desc: Cursed with the habit of reflecting analytically on matters of language, Geoff Pullum tries to figure out why a funny remark by the computer scientist Bjarne Stroustrup is funny. He tried not to, but he couldn’t help himself.
Geoff Pullum laments the falsehoods about English that litter the brains of educated Americans. Yes, there are rules. However, a prohibition on beginning a sentence with “however” is not one of them.

row.c_title: The Case of the Extra Word
row.h_desc: When Geoff Pullum saw a plangently obvious error in The Chronicle, he was sure he knew what had happened. He contacted both the author and the editor to verify his theory. But things were not as he thought.

In early human societies, linguistic communication was two-way and face-to-face. Geoff Pullum finds out just how much things have changed when a stranger tries to badger him into joining a social-media network.
Geoff Pullum ruminates on the practice of publishing overt lies about word usage. One recent example seems harmless, but another is a media-wide effort to defame the president of the United States.
English grammar advice is replete with statements that are easily seen to be false, says Geoff Pullum. Yet they continue to be almost universally accepted.
Geoff Pullum considers a remarkable case in which assessed quality of one genre of prose has recently been found to correspond extremely well with sheer length.

Geoff Pullum reflects on a piece of prescriptive poppycock, and wonders how a shift in function of a single adverb could possibly make anyone think barbarians are at the gates of Western civilization.

row.c_title: Not Rage So Much, but a Modicum of Fear
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum explains why zany misinformation about English grammar, in--of all places--a new column on writing in “The New York Times,” inspires fear, rather than anger, in his heart.
When you put yourself in the media spotlight, you have to expect the blogosphere to nitpick you to death, says Geoff Pullum.

Public discussion of grammar, Geoff Pullum says, is in roughly the state that public understanding of aeronautical engineering would be in if educated adults believed that airplane wings flapped and had feathers.

row.c_title: The Rise and Fall of a Venomous Dispute
row.h_desc: What is the issue in the acrimonious dispute about Daniel Everett’s work? Geoff Pullum says the dispute has dissolved entirely, leaving only the acrimony behind.
During a visit to the Edinburgh Zoo, Geoff Pullum figures out the source of a remarkable piece of erroneous grammar advice that mistakes verbless clausal dangling modifiers for passive clauses.

Geoff Pullum is even more shocked at the current state of science reporting than he is about a false and implausible but much-publicized claim that words spelled with more left-hand keys on the keyboard make you sad.

row.c_title: Foreign Language Education, Part 3: Accentuating the Positive
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum considers where we might look when trying to develop serious arguments in defense of foreign language instruction at the university level.

row.c_title: More on How to Argue for Foreign-Language Instruction
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum returns to the topic of teaching foreign languages despite comments ranging from clueless denialism to personal insults.

row.c_title: How to Argue for Foreign Language Instruction
row.h_desc: To protect the teaching of foreign languages in American universities, says Geoff Pullum, we’ll need to stop relying on feeble arguments about globalization and insights into other cultures.

row.c_title: Literary Judgment Marred by Dumb Grammar Myth
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum looked at the grammatical justification one literary judge gave for relegating a short story to second place, and was appalled.

Geoff Pullum noticed that the linguistics talks he recently attended presupposed knowledge of at least some logic, statistics, information theory, automata, and more. Did he know enough? No. And he thinks that’s great.
Is France right in trying to make it law that the 1915 killings of Armenians in Turkey must be called “genocide”? Geoff Pullum opposes legislative monkeying with lexicography—and with free speech.
Geoff Pullum applauds a case where a writer had a perfect opportunity to moan about the passive but did not take it.
Does any use of nonsubject “who” mark the writer as a grammatical incompetent? Geoff Pullum says anyone who insists on that is a fool.
Geoff Pullum reflects on the process that led to the American Dialect Society’s choice of its Word of the Year.

Discovering the platypus settles the question of whether an animal can have fur and a beak, says Geoff Pullum. But for faith-based grammarians, no kind of evidence can ever prove anything about what’s grammatical.
Who are you supposed to trust on grammar if you can’t trust a native-speaking grammarian’s own considered usage? Geoff Pullum wonders.
Geoff Pullum ruminates on how to answer an unsolicited insulting e-mail from a random stranger.
Don’t be misled: Geoff Pullum exposes a secret pronunciation error, finds dozens more, and explains their name.
Geoff Pullum finds the feeling behind a list of untranslatable relationship words.

row.c_title: More Linguistic Slush From the Arctic
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum is not pleased to run into yet another magazine piece spreading the myth of Eskimo snow vocabulary.

row.c_title: I Will Never Be a Ranter
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum learns what true greatness in the art of the rant really means.
“Permalink” rocketed into English exactly the way “quemmick” didn’t, says Geoff Pullum.
Geoff Pullum tells of a romance sparked by irregular inflectional morphology.

row.c_title: Attack the Muffled Mendacities of the Administrative Creatures
row.h_desc: Rage over adminspeak from a professor emeritus in the U.K. makes Geoff Pullum think of Lovecraft more than Orwell.
Geoff Pullum has his likes and dislikes among neologisms, but that’s not the same as having a general criterion for their viability.

row.c_title: Mistakes Are Made (But Using the Passive Isn’t One of Them)
row.h_desc: Geoff Pullum watches as people who don’t realize they live in glass houses throw unneeded stones to ward off a nonexistent danger.
Does novelist Lee Child know his phonetics? It looked like it, and then it didn’t, says Geoff Pullum.
Geoff Pullum points out that observing a stage in a child’s linguistic behavior is one thing; deciding what conclusion to draw is quite another.
The special relationship between the U.S. and the U.K., says Geoffrey Pullum, doesn’t seem to extend to attitudes toward borrowed words.

row.c_title: In the Time of Declarative Sentences
row.h_desc: A term from the realm of grammar is picked up and used not in its original sense, writes Geoffrey Pullum, but in a sense that the user feels it ought to have.
Thieving is wrong; but what if a colleague handles a lecture interruption with a line that’s just too good not to steal? asks Geoffrey Pullum.
